Sound from microphone is sampled at 44.1Khz  which easily captures audible ranges upto 20 Khz. High speed cameras are designed to capture lots of video frames in a second which gathers lots of frames per second. When we play them it appears slow motion because lots of frames are now playing per second as we all know. The case of sound is a bit different, if we sample lots of millions of samples of sound per second and then play it with normal digital to analog converter of 44.1Khz it will appear as a wierd low frequency sound.

I think it helps to think about this mathematically. So this is my hypothesis on why slow motion cameras don't record sound. When something is recorded at 1/1000 real time and there's a sound that gets slowed down to that extent, that sound is also reduced in frequency by that factor. So a sound recorded at 20 kHz played back at 1/1000 real time (meaning the camera recorded at 30,000 frames per second and played back at 30 FPS), that frequency has to go down to 20 Hz. It goes from one extreme end of the range of human hearing to the other. So a sound wave coming into the microphone at 1 kHz would be replayed at 1 Hz and would be imperceptible to the human ear if it were recorded.
A microphone would ONLY work if the slow motion isn't done to a high degree. Even a factor of 2 makes a huge difference in pitch. It's how the Slow Mo Guys got the background music for all their old videos. It's Synthetic Design 02 from iMovie played back at half speed.
The best way to think about it is to imagine it like a record player. It works by the needle being vibrated by variations in the grooves. If you play a 45 RPM record back at 33 RPM, those variations are hitting the needle at a slower rate and not only will the music slow down, the pitch will drop as well. It does exactly the reverse if you speed a 33 up to 45 RPM. You can actually do this with Audacity and a song or other sound file you have stored on your computer to achieve the same effect.
In summary, a microphone on a slow motion camera is useless because almost any sound it records would have to be pitched so low as to be beyond the bounds of human hearing.

When I was a kid, I broke open six M-80s and poured the contents into an aluminum TV tube case.
(You probably don't know what I'm talking about. Really old TVs with vacuum tubes had some other components that plugged into the same type of base as a vacuum tube. But they weren't glass tubes. They were aluminum cans a bit like a soda can with a pinned base. About 1-1/8" dia. x 3" tall.)
Anyway, when the can was about 2/3 full, I made slits around the open end and folded tabs in against one of the M-80 fuses then sealed it good with epoxy.
Next day, I took it behind my house and tossed it several feet down an embankment. It landed behind a rock. "Shucks!" I thought...I wanted to see it go off and now I cant! It was very loud. The shock wave felt like I was being sand blasted. I was glad the rock was in the way.

Hello SmarterEveryDay, I wanted to propose an idea I have. Perhaps it would be more accurate to record the sound using a purely analog medium like a Vinyl disc or magnetic tape without converting the sound signal to a digital signal at all. This will preserve the "infinite resolution" (more or less infinite sample rate and bit-depth other than thermal noise n stuff) of the analog audio signal. Then you can slow the playback down on a phonograph  proportionally to Youtube's frame-rate compared to the recording camera's frame-rate. This will give you an idea of what it actually sounds like in slow-mo without the heavy frame-draggy / Aliasing-like sounding distortion that comes with slowing down and interpolating the quantized "digital" signal's finite sample rate. You can also manually sync the audio and video with a recording of your hand clapping or something. Though...good luck finding a fully analog recording system in today's day other than eBay USED probably. It's all grandpa tech that is going extinct along with CRT TVs and VHS in this digitally dominated age.

Well technically you could record the sound, but even if you record at a high sample rate (i.e. 192,000Hz or more) and slow the sound down to match the video, the sound waves slowed down would be of such a long wavelength that you wouldn't even hear it. For example, say you have a sound 120,000Hz with a video fps of 600,000. you have 5 frames for every sample of audio. That boils down to a frequency of 0.2Hz which is considerably lower than the lowest frequency audible by humans: roughly 20Hz. Even if you could get a ADC with a speed around 1GHZ and a device capable of picking up ultrasonic frequencies, the sound likely wouldn't be very useful (or likely loud) anyways. In other words, since there is no sound captured with high speed camera's, Foley Sound effects is sometimes used to fill the silence with something that approximates what the sound "should" sound like if it were possible to capture it, making the high speed video more Interesting and Entertaining.  When I was shooting high speed videos on my channel with my Casio EXILIM Pro EX-F1 High Speed Camera, I filled the silence with background music.which tended to be Classical Music, which fit very well with automatic weapons fire etc..  I just started using basic Foley when my desktop computer fried.  one day my channel will return, but until then there is a lot of great content to watch on YouTube, such as Smarter Every Day and other's.   It was great to see that other channels are using Foley to bring better content to it's subscribers.   Way To Go !

At 5'44" : "Gordon is recording with these microphones"... Oh my, interesting info. Now let's be serious : what microphones ?  Nice video as usual and the sound is not "faked". The "real" sound would sound (and be) fake if slowed down proportionally to the video.  Hearing and seeing are not the same. Every sound effect engineer knows for a fact that most "real" sounds will sound fake, be it steps, echoes, explosions or nature sound, because there are plenty of "parasite" sounds recorded too. It's even worse with transposed sounds, because they will lack a good part of their spectrum.  So that it's better (and, in a way, more truthful) to "reinvent " the sound so that it will sound real.  and, yes, it's an "artistic technology".

LOVE this guy -

While, as an audio engineer, I greatly appreciate the in-depth view into the process of sfx creation, I am a bit disappointed that, at no point during this video was any reference to the name of this process made. What you are doing is called Foley, and it is a massive industry utilized in the production of almost every modern film ever made. This process, and another called "Automated Dialog Replacement" (ADR) are routinely employed to create the sonic landscape that accompanies the images on the screen. There are some really neat videos out there on how some of the big production houses (like ILM and Disney) make the audio magic happen, and it is a lot of fun to see how an independent operates. Fyi, it is strikingly similar, right down to the subbing of audio sources (i.e., orange for tomato, etc.). Thanks for helping make the world smarter in a really cool way, and please share more behind the scenes videos like this.

If anyone is confused you can't use the original audio because it is recorded at a sample rate of usually 44.1 or 48kHz. If you stretch this audio to match the picture you are decreasing the amount of samples per second. Some software have algorithms to try and fill in where the empty samples would be but this usually adds horrible artifacts. Therefore it is easier to recreate the sound in post-production with Foley and high audio manipulation to make a more pleasing, fitting sound.

There are a lot of reasons why you can't record "slow motion" like video and that it's not just a case of playing back a slow sound file. Sound files are already captured at really high sample rates (48,000 samples per second). Primarily though, the main problem is straight up that sound takes too long to physically happen (well... and playing back a sound slowly is still producing a physical phenomenon that never existed... if an explosion was slower, it would have entirely different acoustic properties, not just the same...over a longer period of time).

Even a sound as sudden and impulsive as a firecracker will still be reverberating and travelling through the air to the microphone by the time the tomato has exploded. Any sound of the squishing fruit would be completely obscured.

I wonder if you could hook a microphone up to an oscilloscope with a large buffer and record audio with that, since the sample rate is in the gigasamples per second, I assume something recorded at 1,000,000,000 samples/sec would be perfect for ultra-slow mo playback at 48,000 samples/sec like normal audio. You’d need a pretty small microphone diaphragm to get the kind of frequency response you’d need to get anything in the audible range.

A rigol ds1054z with it’s 12M sample memory could do 12ms of real-time audio recorded at 1,000,000,000 samples/second. Played back at 48,000 samples/second, that’s 250 seconds of audio for an effective overall playback speed of 0.000048x.

Why not use Fourier?
I know little about sound but i am not sold on using special effects and not actual sound, but i understand you cant just slow it down by x100
Try recording with the best mic you have, or two mics with different gains (to catch high and low amplitudes, then combine them digitaly), convert from temporal to a spectrogram (Fourier transform with variable window size, ie small window for high frequencies, larg window for lower frequency, to minimize distortion due to next step), stretch it out (frequency will not change, only duration) but to only about 1/3 of the length needed, convert back to time domain (inverse Fourier) and now stretch it out more to the remaining needed length (this will change the pitch and making it sound "sycho-whatever" but because its only a factor of x3 it should still be audible), finally a bit of time syncing and normalization to suppress the highs and amplify the lows.

These firecrackers most commonly have a small capsule with up to 50 mg of powder and a fuse in it. Surrounding the capsule is plaster or a similar material, and finally a red tube and two plastic end caps. Because of the size of these firecrackers, buyers are occasionally deceived into thinking that the entire tube is full. Also the fuse, at times, protrudes from the ends of these firecrackers, as opposed to the middle of the tube in real M-80s. Genuine M-80s have paper end caps, and contain 50–60 times more powder.

For those that think there is a good alternative to faking the sound, you have to first understand how sound works. Frequency is the number of wavelengths that pass the observer each second. We hear frequencies between roughly 20hz-20khz. Now if you're recording at 5k times faster speeds(60fps x 5k = 300kfps, only about half what he said the camera could record at) and playing back(20khz/5k=4hz, too low to hear), you've lost all of the audible information. Your options are fake sound, no sound or play music.... I like the fake sounds.

I've always found the use of foley sounds grating in slow motion videos. Most things you don't have experience with don't sound as you expect.

E.g. you've all seen nuclear test films; what you should have seen was a brilliant flash and mushroom cloud in complete awkward silence, and then 20 seconds or so later, the trees bend forward a little bit and a fraction of a second later you hear a loud thundercrack. Nothing like the deep rumbling you've heard, that was just a foley effect. You can see what it would really be like on the upshot-knothole annie test.

The least dishonest thing to do is to simply not have sound. A perhaps a less dishonest way of having some sound is to record at fairly high sample rates and process the data to extract the frequencies that are present in each moment so that they can be stretched to play at the same rate as the video. That way a 440 Hz tone is still a 440 Hz tone, it just repeats for many more cycles than it really should have and It'd still be wrong, but there's potentially some interesting information there.

Of course, when it comes to sound.... Slowing down sound would require a very high sample rate.
But... stretched far enough you'd end up with pretty much everything being ultra low frequency sound that is basically inaudible.
(even if you could hear it your speakers or headphones couldn't reproduce it.)

You could of course use a filter to slow it down without changing the pitch, but that's probably not going to work past a certain point either...

Slow motion sound kinda doesn't work because sound is a time-based signal, where vision is partially at least a spatial signal...
